transcript:
Patient: You know, I've been so focused on just applying to as many jobs as possible, but maybe I need to be more strategic about it.

Therapist: That's an interesting idea, Emilio. Being strategic in your job search could help you feel more in control of the process. What would a more strategic approach look like for you?

Patient: I think I need to spend more time researching companies and tailoring my applications to each specific job. I've just been sending out the same generic resume and cover letter, but that's probably not the most effective approach.

Therapist: You're right, tailoring your application materials to each job can make a big difference. It shows the employer that you've taken the time to understand their needs and how you can meet them. It's also a way to highlight your most relevant skills and experiences.

Patient: Definitely. It's just hard to stay motivated to put in that extra effort when I'm already feeling so discouraged.

Therapist: That's understandable. Discouragement can really sap your motivation. What do you think might help you stay motivated, even in the face of setbacks?

Patient: I think setting smaller, achievable goals could help. Like, instead of just saying "I need to find a job," I could set a goal of researching three companies this week and tailoring my application to one job posting.

Therapist: That's a great idea! Breaking the process down into smaller, more manageable steps can make it feel less overwhelming. And each time you achieve one of those smaller goals, it can give you a sense of accomplishment and momentum.

Patient: Yeah, I like that idea. I think I'll try setting some smaller goals for myself this week and see how it goes.

Therapist: Fantastic! I'm excited to hear how it works out for you. Remember, even small progress is still progress, and every step counts.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. I'll do my best to keep that in mind.

Therapist: You're welcome, Emilio. I have faith in you and your ability to keep moving forward, even when it's tough.

Now, I want to circle back to something you mentioned earlier about feeling embarrassed when you receive a job rejection. Can you tell me more about that?

Patient: Well, I guess I feel like I should be able to get a job easily, since I have a Master's degree. When I get rejected, it feels like a personal failure, like I'm not living up to my potential.

Therapist: That's a really common feeling, Emilio. It's easy to tie our sense of self-worth to our professional achievements, especially when we've invested a lot of time and energy into our education and training. But the truth is, the job market is unpredictable and often unfair. Not getting a job doesn't mean you're a failure or that you're not living up to your potential.

Patient: I know that logically, but it's hard to really believe it emotionally.

Therapist: That's where self-compassion can be really helpful. When you're feeling embarrassed or like a failure, try to talk to yourself the way you would talk to a good friend who was going through the same thing. What would you say to them?

Patient: I guess I would remind them that their worth isn't defined by their job status, and that everyone faces rejection at some point. I would tell them to be kind to themselves and not beat themselves up over it.

Therapist: Exactly! And you deserve that same kindness and understanding from yourself. When those feelings of embarrassment or failure come up, try to respond to yourself with that same compassion and encouragement.

Patient: I'll try to do that. It's not easy, but I can see how it could help.

Therapist: It definitely takes practice, but it's a skill that can make a big difference in how you relate to yourself and your experiences. And the more you practice, the more natural it will start to feel.

Patient: I guess it's kind of like building a muscle, in a way.

Therapist: That's a great analogy, Emilio! Self-compassion is like a muscle that gets stronger the more you use it. And just like with physical exercise, consistency is key. The more you practice, even in small ways, the more you'll start to see the benefits.

Patient: That makes sense. I'll try to be more consistent with my self-compassion practice, even if it feels awkward at first.

Therapist: That's a great plan! And remember, it's okay if it feels awkward or difficult at times. That's just part of the process of learning a new skill.

Now, I want to shift gears a bit and talk about your sleep. Last session, we discussed creating a consistent bedtime routine to help improve your sleep quality. How has that been going?
